posts.text: Bought this washer this month, install and balance by home depot delivery team.Installation went well, the next day did the 1st wash load just 3 towels to try it out and the door of the washer look like it was going to open on the spin sickle. Washer shakes more then my old ones second load (small load of color clothes) washer started liking from the bottom part of the door nothing was obstructing the door from the seal and water was coming out from the bottom of the washer not a tun but enough to make a puddle and this was the first time we used the washer return the washer the next day in my opinion its a nice machine nice features love the tilt of the drum and steam cycle and how it washes but the door is build cheep for how much the price on this washer is.

posts.author: TBD
posts.title: VIDEO: Pediatric vaccine updates discussed at IDC New York
posts.text: VIDEO: Pediatric vaccine updates discussed at IDC New York December 6, 2017 NEW YORK – Mark H. Sawyer, MD, discussed what’s new in pediatric vaccinations during his presentation at the 2017 Infectious Diseases in Children Symposium. Sawyer, a professor of clinical pediatrics at the University of California San Diego School of Medicine who practices at Rady Children’s Hospital San Diego, discussed developments in the past year, including using one repeat hepatitis B vaccine instead of three doses for infants who did not respond to the first dose of the vaccine at birth and were born to mothers at high risk. Among other developments, he discussed giving a third dose of the MMR vaccine, which is typically a two-dose vaccine. NEW YORK – Mark H. posts.author: DARREL RADFORD News-Gazette Managing Editor
posts.title: Wanted: State representative for 2019 session
posts.text:
Greg Beumer’s decision to not seek 
re-election opens door for newcomer 
to file beginning Wednesday, Jan. 10 
Randolph County Economic Development Director Greg Beumer created a unique job opportunity for someone living here Tuesday by announcing he would not seek re-election to his District 33 seat in the Indiana House of Representatives. 
“My announcement was made to let people who may have an interest in running time to make a decision,” said Beumer, who will hold office through the 2018 Indiana General Assembly up to next November’s election. “Multiple people should have the opportunity to serve in the General Assembly. “Let’s let others step up and have an opportunity to see what they can do.” 
The Modoc Republican said even though he’s slated to serve another year, time is of the essence for those who would like to succeed him. The filing period for state and local offices begins Wednesday, Jan 10 and runs through Friday, Feb. 9. So there’s a limited window of time. 
“You would want someone who gave it careful consideration,” Beumer said. “It does take time away from family. It’s a commitment.” 
While labeled a “part-time” legislature, holding a seat in the House of Representatives requires more time than meets the outsider’s eye, according to Beumer, who said he routinely handles phone calls and emails connected to the Statehouse year round, not just when the Indiana General Assembly is in session during the winter and early spring months. 
“During session, my typical schedule was to leave for Indianapolis every Sunday and not come home Thursday night,” Beumer said. “Check with your family. It will impact your family life — and not just while you’re in session. Every single day I’ve had at least an email and a phone call. But serving as as state representative has been a rewarding experience, Beumer said, for reasons the general public might not expect. 
“A lot of people think it’s about authoring and passing legislation,” Beumer said. “First and foremost it’s about providing constituent services and being able to help people in distress over problems with governmental agencies.” 
During his time in office — which began in October of 2013 when incumbent Bill Davis resigned — Beumer said he was able to help a single mom with child in need of surgery cut through red tape to access some of her state retirement funds. It was just one of many examples Beumer has, quietly, behind-the-scenes made a difference in his Statehouse role. 
“My biggest single disappointment is not being able to get legislation passed waiving the requirement that city court judges have to be attorneys.” - State Rep. Greg Beumer 
“State Senators and State Representatives have a lot of influence and can help people solve some of these issues if they use a common-sense approach,” Beumer said. 
Beumer is a well-known public servant in Randolph County. He first attempted to win a Statehouse seat in 1992 when State Rep. David Hoover decided not to run but narrowly lost to Ron Liggett. 
That loss, though, by about 200 votes, turned out to be Randolph County’s gain, as Beumer went on to serve as a County Commissioner from 1993 to 2000 and later as a member of the Union School Board. 
Getting legislation authored and passed is difficult in the best of circumstances and nearly impossible in the worst ones. Beumer said his biggest regret was not being able to change the way city court judges are chosen in Indiana. 
“My biggest single disappointment is not being able to get legislation passed waiving the requirement that city court judges have to be attorneys,” Beumer said. 
Beumer explained City Court Judges only deal with issues they can’t send offenders to jail for like traffic citations or city ordinance violations, so no law degree would be required. 
Because a law degree is required, some cities are struggling, according to Beumer. He said the Dunkirk City Court had to close because there was no one available with a law degree to take the job. 
Beumer said he didn’t plan to file another bill in an attempt to change the law, since this will be a “short” session. Deadline to file legislation is Dec. 8. 
Beumer’s district covers all of Randolph and Jay counties in addition to the eastern third of Delaware County. 
Beumer said anyone interested in running for his House of Representatives seat and who has questions may call him at 765-238-0365. This article originally ran on winchesternewsgazette.com .

posts.title: Bought a parts C-5060 For...:
posts.text:
$26.05 off of eBay shipped. It was in much nicer condition than expected. The parts that I got were:
1. Olympus brand BLM-1 battery (good)
2. Lens Cap
3. OEM Strap
4. SanDisk Extreme III 2GB CF card
5. 32MB XD card
6. Hot shoe Cap
7. Battery door
And of course the rest of the C-5060. It has firmware V756-82.
It does not power on with a fully charged BLM-1 or a new Olympus AC adapter.
Anyone have any idea what might be wrong? Mode switch module maybe?
Thanks!

What a Day This Has Been 

December 7, 1732…In central London, the original Theatre Royal, Covent Garden was opened. The current building is the third theatre on the site following fires in 1808 and 1857. It is now called the Royal Opera House. 
December 7, 1796… John Adams was elected to be the second president of the United States. 
December 7, 1817…British Royal Navy Vice Admiral William Bligh , remembered for the historic mutiny that occurred during his command of HMS Bounty, died at the age of 63. 
December 7, 1836… Martin Van Buren was elected to be the eighth president of the United States. 
December 7, 1869…In Gallatin, Missouri, the outlaw Jesse James committed his first confirmed bank robbery. 
December 7, 1902…Editorial cartoonist ( Harper's Weekly ) Thomas Nast , considered to be the "Father of the American cartoon," died of yellow fever at age 62. 
December 7, 1925…Swimmer Johnny Weissmuller set a world record in the 150-yard freestyle with a time of 1 minute, 25 and 2/5 seconds. He went on to play "Tarzan" in the movies. 
December 7, 1930…In Boston, W1XAV aired video from the CBS radio orchestra program "The Fox Trappers." The broadcast included the first television commercial , an ad for I.J. Fox Furriers, the radio show's sponsor. 
December 7, 1941… The Imperial Japanese Navy conducted a surprise military strike against the United States naval base at Pearl Harbor , Hawaii. The base was attacked by a total of 353 Japanese aircraft, in two waves, launched from six aircraft carriers. Four U.S. Navy battleships were sunk and four others were damaged. The Japanese also sank or damaged three cruisers, three destroyers, an anti-aircraft training ship and a minelayer. A total of 188 U.S. aircraft were destroyed, 2,402 American personnel were killed and 1,282 were wounded. 
December 7, 1946…At the Winecoff Hotel (now the Ellis Hotel) in Atlanta, America's deadliest hotel fire killed 119 people, including the hotel's owners. 
December 7, 1954… Marty Robbins became the first major artist to cover an Elvis Presley tune when he recorded Arthur Crudup's "That's All Right." It became a Top Ten hit on the Billboard Country chart. 
December 7, 1956… Alan Freed 's " Rock, Rock, Rock " opened in U.S. movie theaters, featuring Chuck Berry, Frankie Lymon and The Teenagers, the Flamingos, the Moonglows, La Vern Baker, the Johnny Burnette Trio, Teddy Randazzo , and the voice of Connie Francis subbing for 13-year-old actress Tuesday Weld. 
December 7, 1956…Singer Helen O'Connell joined NBC-TV's "Today" show. 
December 7, 1959… Kitty Kallen sang "Little Things Mean A Lot" on ABC-TV's "American Bandstand." 
December 7, 1961…In Dallas, Texas, Johnny Cash and June Carter appeared on stage together the first time. 
December 7, 1963… Instant replay was used for the first time during the Army-Navy game on CBS-TV. 
December 7, 1963…The Beatles appeared as panelists on the BBC-TV show "Juke Box Jury" to rate new record releases. The Fab Four turned thumbs down on Bobby Vinton's "There, I've Said It Again," which was currently #1 in the U.S., but Elvis Presley's latest single, "Kiss Me Quick," was declared "a hit." 
December 7, 1963… Neil Sedaka and Vito and the Salutations were guest performers on ABC-TV's "American Bandstand." 
December 7, 1964…Beach Boy Brian Wilson married Marilyn Rovell. They had two daughters before divorcing in 1979. 
December 7, 1966… Nancy Sinatra appeared with her father on the CBS-TV special, " Frank Sinatra: A Man And His Music Part II ." 
December 7, 1967…The Beatles' Apple boutique opened in London. It closed seven months later and all its merchandise was given away to passersby. 
December 7, 1968… Eric Burdon announced he would break up the Animals after a December 22 concert in Newcastle, England, then go to California to begin an acting career. 
December 7, 1969…The 5 th Dimension sang "Wedding Bell Blues," and Ferrante & Teicher played the theme from "Midnight Cowboy" on CBS-TV's "The Ed Sullivan Show." Tony Sandler & Ralph Young, Imogene Coca, Richard Tucker and Ron Carey also performed on the program. 
December 7, 1970… Harry Reasoner joined Howard K. Smith to co-anchor "The ABC Evening News," a pairing that lasted almost five years. 
December 7, 1970…Cartoonist ( Mike and Ike-They Look Alike, Boob McNutt, Foolish Questions, Lala Palooza, The Weekly Meeting of the Tuesday Women's Club )/sculptor/author/screenwriter ( Soup to Nuts )/inventor Rube Goldberg , who created the cartoon character Professor Lucifer Gorgonzola Butts, died of cancer at the age of 87. 
December 7, 1971…Paul McCartney's new band, Wings , released their first album, "Wild Life." 
December 7, 1972… Imelda Marcos , wife of Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, was stabbed and seriously wounded by an assailant who was then shot and killed by her bodyguards. 
December 7, 1972…At Cape Canaveral, Florida, NASA launched Apollo 17 , the last U.S. Apollo moon mission. 
December 7, 1973…After just three months on the job, newspaper writer ( The Washington Post )/author Sally Quinn resigned as TV co-host of "The CBS Morning News." 
December 7, 1974… Andy Kim and Al Wilson guested on ABC-TV's "American Bandstand." 
December 7, 1975…Playwright ( Our Town, The Skin of Our Teeth )/novelist ( The Bridge of San Luis Rey, The Eighth Day ) Thornton Wilder died after a heart attack at age 78. 
December 7, 1977… Peter Goldmark , developer of the LP (long playing) 33 1/3 rpm record and the first commercial color television system, was killed in a car accident at the age of 71. 
December 7, 1982…At a prison in Huntsville, Texas, convicted murderer Charlie Brooks, Jr. became the first person in the U.S. executed by lethal injection . 
December 7, 1983…In Madrid, Spain, an Aviaco DC-9 collided on a runway with an Iberia Air Lines Boeing 727 that was accelerating for takeoff. The accident resulted in the deaths of 93 people. 
December 7, 1983…The Kenny Rogers-Dolly Parton duet single "Islands in the Stream'' was certified Platinum. 
December 7, 1984… Michael Jackson testified in Chicago that he, not an Illinois man, wrote the song "The Girl is Mine." Jackson won the case. 
December 7, 1984…Actress ( Yankee Doodle Dandy, Quicksand, The Time of Your Life )/television fashion commentator ( Queen for a Day ) Jeanne Cagney , sister of actor James Cagney, died of lung cancer at age 65. 
December 7, 1985… Roseanne Cash sang "Never Be You" on ABC-TV's "American Bandstand." 
December 7, 1985… John Lithgow hosted NBC-TV's "Saturday Night Live," with a guest appearance by comedian Sam Kinison . Musical guest Mr. Mister performed "Broken Wings" and "Kyrie." 
December 7, 1985…Former U.S. Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart died after a stroke at age 70. 
December 7, 1987…A gunman opened fire on fellow passengers and the two pilots aboard a Pacific Southwest Airlines jetliner. In all, 43 people were killed. 
December 7, 1987…Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev arrived in the U.S. for his first visit . He had been invited to a Washington summit with President Ronald Reagan. 
December 7, 1987…In New York City, Bruce Springsteen, Judy Collins, Harry Belafonte, Pete Seeger, Kenny Rogers, Peter Paul & Mary, Pat Benatar, the Smothers Brothers and Paul Simon , were among those who took the stage at Carnegie Hall to pay tribute to Harry Chapin on what would have been his 45 th birthday. That same day, Chapin posthumously received a Congressional Gold Medal for his work in fighting hunger. 
December 7, 1987…R&B singer ( Kiss And Say Goodbye, Shining Star ) Richard Taylor of the Manhattans died at age 47. 
December 7, 1988…More than 25,000 people were killed in Armenia by an earthquake measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale. There were 30,000 injuries and 500,000 people were left homeless. 
December 7, 1988…Actor ( Peyton Place, Manhattan Baby, 1990: The Bronx Warriors, Benji, Strike Commando, Cobra Mission, Foxtrap, They Only Kill Their Masters, Night of the Sharks ) Christopher Connelly died of lung cancer at 47. 
December 7, 1989…The Communist Party in East Germany agreed to cooperate with a proposal for free elections and a revised constitution . 
December 7, 1990…CNN founder Ted Turner and actress Jane Fonda announced their engagement. They married on December 21, 1991, the third marriage for both. They divorced in May 2001. 
December 7, 1990…Actress ( Dark Shadows, Father's Little Dividend, Father of the Bride, Scarlet Street, House of Dark Shadows, The Man in the Iron Mask, We're No Angels, Little Women, Me and My Gal, For Heaven's Sake, The Son of Monte Cristo, The Macomber Affair ) Joan Bennett died following a heart attack at 80. 
December 7, 1990…Soul singer ( Raindrops, Hey Little Girl, Just Keep It Up, Nobody But You ) Dee Clark died following a heart attack at age 52. 
December 7, 1993…In Nassau County, New York, passenger Colin Ferguson murdered six people and injured 19 others on the Long Island Railroad . 
December 7, 1993…U.S. Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary revealed that the American government had authorized more than 200 nuclear weapons tests , conducted in secret, at its Nevada test site. 
December 7, 1993…U.S. Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders made the controversial suggestion that the government should study the impact of drug legalization . 
December 7, 1993…Singer/actor Robert Goulet underwent prostate cancer surgery. 
December 7, 1995…Six years after it was launched by Space Shuttle Atlantis, the Galileo spacecraft arrived at Jupiter to study the planet and its moons, and became the first Earth-launched spacecraft to orbit Jupiter . In 2003, the mission was terminated and Galileo was sent to disintegrate in Jupiter's atmosphere. 
December 7, 1996…Jerry Lewis' $9,000 white and red pinstriped devil suit , which he wore for the role of Satan in the musical "Damn Yankees," was taken from his dressing room at Shea's Performing Arts Center in Buffalo. 
December 7, 1998…Jazz trumpeter Arturo Sandoval was granted U.S. citizenship after a six-year struggle with the Immigration and Naturalization Service. 
December 7, 1999…A U.S. federal grand jury indicted a former convict in the disappearance of atheist leader Madalyn Murray O'Hair four years earlier. David Roland Waters, who had worked as a typesetter for American Atheists, was found guilty of kidnapping, robbery, and murder, then sentenced to 20 years in prison, where he died of lung cancer in 2003. 
December 7, 1999…The Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) launched a lawsuit against the on-line, file-sharing company Napster , seeking $100,000 in damages for each song copied. 
December 7, 2000…The movie " Cast Away ," starring Tom Hanks, Helen Hunt, and Paul Sanchez, had its world premiere in Los Angeles. 
December 7, 2001… Gary Allan 's album "Smoke Rings In The Dark" was certified Platinum. 
December 7, 2002… Two Van Gogh paintings , "View of the Sea st Scheveningen" and "Congregation Leaving the Reformed Church in Nuenen," were stolen from the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, Netherlands. In July 2004, two men were convicted of the crime and both were sentenced to at least four years in prison. 
December 7, 2003…Hip-hop soul singer/songwriter Mary J. Blige married her manager Martin Kendu Isaacs. She filed for divorce in July 2016. 
December 7, 2004…Country music singer/bandleader Jerry Scoggins , who sang "The Ballad of Jed Clampett," theme song of the TV sitcom "The Beverly Hillbillies," died at the age of 93. 
December 7, 2006…Diplomat/former U.S. United Nations ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick died of heart failure at age 80. 
December 7, 2006…Jazz/blues pianist/singer ( Ain't Nobody's Business, Confessin' The Blues ) Blues Hall of Famer Jay McShann died at the age of 90. 
December 7, 2007… Rosanne Cash , the 52-year-old daughter of the late country music legend Johnny Cash, returned home after undergoing brain surgery. 
December 7, 2007… Ray Charles Plaza with a revolving, bronze sculpture of Charles seated at a piano, was dedicated in his hometown of Albany, Georgia. 
December 7, 2008…Singer ( Traces, Stormy, Spooky ) Dennis Yost , lead vocalist of the Classics IV, died of respiratory failure at the age of 65. He had been in a nursing home since suffering a brain injury in a 2005 fall. 
December 7, 2009… Bette Midler performed for Britain's Queen Elizabeth II at the Royal Variety Show in Blackburn, England. 
December 7, 2010… Elizabeth Edwards , estranged wife of 2008 U.S. presidential candidate John Edwards, died of metastatic breast cancer at the age of 61. 
December 7, 2011…Former Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich was sentenced to 14 years in federal prison for corruption and extortion. On March 15, 2012, he reported to prison in Littleton, Colorado, where he will serve at least 85% – 12 years – of his sentence before the possibility of release. 
December 7, 2011…Folksinger ( Michael, Cotton Fields, The Gypsy Rover ) Bob Burnett of the Highwaymen died of brain cancer at 71. 
December 7, 2011…Actor ( M*A*S*H, Dragnet 1967, December Bride, Pete & Gladys, After MASH, The Richard Boone Show, High Noon, The Ox-Bow Incident, The Glenn Miller Story, Inherit the Wind, The Apple Dumpling Gang, Support Your Local Sheriff!, The Shootist, The Teahouse of the August Moon, Madame Bovary, Orchestra Wives, A Bell for Adano, To the Shores of Tripoli ) Harry Morgan died at the age of 96. 
December 7, 2012…One of the world's most acclaimed psychics (who accurately predicted the deaths of John F. Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy, Jack Benny, Howard Hughes and, two weeks before Chappaquiddick, told Ted Kennedy he would be involved in an accident near water, his companion would die, but he would be uninjured), Irene Hughes , a frequent guest on the Merv Griffin and Regis Philbin TV shows, died at age 92. 
December 7, 2012…Tennis Hall of Famer Art Larsen , whose career was marked by eccentricity and cut short by a 1956 motor scooter accident that nearly killed him, died at the age of 87. 
December 7, 2013…Actress Kate Winslet and her husband Ned Rocknroll welcomed the arrival of son Bear. 
December 7, 2014…Actor ( Pandorum, American Gangster, Pineapple Express, The Number 23, The Fortune Theory, Nature Calls ) Eddie Rouse died of liver failure at age 60. 
December 7, 2014…Actor ( The Addams Family )/cartoon voicist ( The Addams Family ) Ken Weatherwax , nephew of Lassie owner/trainer Rudd Weatherwax, died following a heart attack at 59. 
December 7, 2015…Actor ( General Hospital, The Bionic Woman, The Six Million Dollar Man, Dallas, Search for Tomorrow, Colossus: The Forbin  Project, T-Force, The Man ) Martin E. Brooks died at the age of 90. 
December 7, 2016…A Pakistan International Airways passenger plane, on its way from Chitral to Islamabad, crashed about 43 miles from its destination, killing all 47 people on board . One of those who perished was pop singer-turned Islamic preacher Junaid Jamshed. 
December 7, 2016…Singer/songwriter/musician/producer ( Lucky Man, I Believe In Father Christmas, The Court Of The Crimson King ) Greg Lake , a member of Emerson, Lake & Palmer and King Crimson in addition to his solo work, died of cancer at 69. 


I Did Not Know That! 
For every extra kilogram carried on a space flight, 530 kg of excess fuel is needed at lift-off. 





Do something for somebody every day for which you do not get paid. - Albert Schweitzer 

Enjoy your day!  Make it matter.

posts.title: Viral Videos: The Most-Viewed Music Videos On YouTube For 2017
posts.text:
YouTube has released its list of the most-viewed music videos of the year.
What were the most-viewed music videos on YouTube this year?
The top spot went to “Despacito”, which isn’t a surprise, because with over 4.4 billion hits in just 11 months, it’s already the most-viewed video of all time. Here are the Top 10 MUSIC VIDEOS, globally:

thread.title: State OKs health insurance plan for Gary schools that saves money, reduces debt
thread.title_full: State OKs health insurance plan for Gary schools that saves money, reduces debt

posts.author: Dan Carden dan.carden@nwi.com, 317-637-9078
posts.title: State OKs health insurance plan for Gary schools that saves money, reduces debt
posts.text:
State OKs health insurance plan for Gary schools that saves money, reduces debt Dan Carden dan.carden@nwi.com, 317-637-9078 
Micah Vincent, chairman of the Indiana Distressed Unit Appeals Board, reviews documents relating to health insurance for Gary Community School Corp. employees as DUAB Executive Director Courtney Schaafsma looks on Monday at the Indiana Government Center in Indianapolis. Dan Carden, The Times Save 
INDIANAPOLIS — The emergency management firm operating the Gary Community School Corp. won state approval Monday for a health insurance contract that minimizes premium increases and potentially eliminates $2.3 million in debt. 
The Indiana Distressed Unit Appeals Board voted 4-0 to authorize Gary Schools Recovery, Inc., to maintain Cigna as the health insurance provider for the cash-strapped district's 380 employees. 
They'll see a 5.9 percent premium increase in January compared to 2017 rates. Though that's lower than the 8.94 percent rate hike Cigna initially proposed. 
Perhaps more importantly, Cigna agreed to waive $1.3 million owed by the district because recent school employee health care costs significantly exceeded the premiums paid. 
The health insurance company also pledged to reduce by $1 million the district's $2.8 million in overdue premium payments if the district signed a two-year contract, continues paying $150,000 a month toward the debt and does not miss any payments over the next year. 
"We must be timely with our payments, including the $150,000 payback on what would now be $1.8 million," said Peggy Hinckley, the district's emergency manager. "If we miss the $150,000 in any month then the $1 million comes back as a judgment." 
In addition, Cigna promised not to increase 2019 rates by more than 10 percent compared to 2018. 
DUAB Chairman Micah Vincent noted that Cigna's total two-year cost of $12,009,060 exceeded Anthem's bid by $1,142,795. 
But with Cigna's concessions on rates and past due amounts — which still would be owed if the district switched providers — he said Cigna will end up being $1,157,205 less expensive for the district, which regularly relies on state loans to fund operations. 
"When you go through that calculation, Cigna becomes the better option for Gary Community Schools," said Eric Parish, executive vice president of MGT Consulting Group, parent company of the Gary emergency management firm. 
New DUAB members 
Also on Monday, Gov. Eric Holcomb named former state Rep. Rebecca Kubacki, R-Syracuse, as his representative on the Distressed Unit Appeals Board that's overseeing the state takeover of the Gary Community School Corp. 
Kubacki served two terms in the Indiana House between 2010 and 2014. She was defeated by state Rep. Curt Nisly, R-Goshen, in the 2014 Republican primary, in part because Kubacki voted against a proposed state constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage. 
This year's Senate Enrolled Act 567 gave the governor a direct appointment to DUAB, replacing a member formerly selected by Indiana House and Senate leadership. 
In addition to Kubacki, the other voting members are: Micah Vincent, DUAB chairman, Indiana Office of Management and Budget; Wesley Bennett, Department of Local Government Finance; Paul Joyce, State Board of Accounts; and Kent Hatcher, Department of Education. 
Legislative leaders now pick advisory members for the board. Last month, state Sen. Eric Bassler, R-Washington, replaced state Sen. Ryan Mishler, R-Bremen, after Mishler was named chairman of the budget-writing Senate Appropriations Committee. 
The other legislative advisers are state Rep. Milo Smith, R-Columbus; and state Sen. Eddie Melton, D-Merrillville. 
Former DLGF Commissioner Courtney Schaafsma is DUAB's executive director. This article originally ran on nwitimes.com .

thread.section_title: Family Medicine News
thread.title: Confirmatory HIV testing prevents unnecessary treatment in infants
thread.title_full: Confirmatory HIV testing prevents unnecessary treatment in infants

posts.author: TBD
posts.title: Confirmatory HIV testing prevents unnecessary treatment in infants
posts.text: Dunning L, et al. PLoS Med. 2017. doi: 10.1371/journal.pmed.1002446 December 6, 2017 The use of a second, confirmatory HIV test for infants in South Africa can reduce the number of false-positive results from 128 to 1 per 1,000 infants and is able to save costs related to unneeded treatment, according to a study published in PLOS Medicine. “As the incidence of pediatric HIV falls with improved access to ART for pregnant and breast-feeding women, the positive predictive value of diagnostic assays also decreases, leading to a greater proportion of uninfected infants receiving false-positive diagnoses and starting ART,” Lorna Dunning, MBiochem, MPH, from the division of epidemiology and biostatistics in the School of Public Health & Family Medicine at the University of Cape Town, and colleagues wrote. “After ART is initiated, it may be impossible to distinguish truly infected infants from uninfected infants because effective ART may lead to undetectable HIV RNA in HIV-infected infants whilst also preventing the development of endogenous anti-HIV antibody after maternal antibody fades from the circulation,” Dunning and colleagues continued. “Because truly infected infants may therefore have identical laboratory results to treated infected infants, they may face many years or even a lifetime of incorrect diagnosis and ART.” To examine whether a second, confirmatory HIV test for children in early infancy demonstrates cost-efficacy and is impactful in preventing false diagnoses, the researchers conducted a simulation using the Cost-effectiveness of Preventing AIDS Complications-Pediatric model. The simulation included early infant diagnosis testing for infants aged 6 weeks who were exposed to HIV . Children who received confirmatory testing, and those who did not, were included. Regarding nucleic acid amplification tests, Dunning and colleagues assumed each test would cost $25 (U.S.), with a specificity of 99.6%. For infants who were infected with HIV in utero or at least 4 weeks before testing was completed, the researchers assumed the test had a sensitivity of 100% and a mother-to-child transmission rate of 4.9% for those aged 12 months. The researchers then simulated the rates of testing uptake, result return and ART initiation according to previously established guidelines. All infants were connected with care and treated over 10 years if they had false-positive results and for life if they had true positive results. Of those included in the simulation with HIV, life expectancy remained the same whether or not confirmatory testing was completed (26.2 years). Those who were exposed to HIV had a life expectancy of 61.4 years. When confirmatory testing was not conducted, 128/1,000 infants who had false-positive results began ART . This number was significantly lower when confirmatory testing was completed (1/1,000). The use of confirmatory testing was observed as cost-saving. The cost for a single infant with confirmatory testing equated to $1,790, whereas the cost without additional testing was equal to $1,830 per infant. The cost-efficacy did not change unless the infant underwent a nucleic acid amplification test that cost more than $400 or if a false-positive status was diagnosed, identified and ART was stopped within 3 months. “False-positive results occur for a variety of reasons but are likely the result of stretched human resources compromising test specificity and sensitivity via specimen handling errors such as mislabeling of specimens, incorrect specimen placement in the device or inadequate quality control resulting in contamination between specimens during PCR amplification,” Dunning and colleagues wrote. “WHO recommends the use of a second specimen for a confirmatory test, ensuring the independence of the two assays and reducing the likelihood of a false-positive result.” “Unconfirmed [early infant diagnosis] test results therefore cause diagnostic dilemmas for the provider, whilst families may experience confusion and uncertainty about the health system, discouraging future engagement in care,” Dunning and colleagues continued. – by Katherine Bortz Disclosures: The authors report no relevant financial disclosures. thread.section_title: elevatormusik
thread.title: Edinburgh: Zen Lifestyle Spa & Salon
thread.title_full: Edinburgh: Zen Lifestyle Spa & Salon

posts.author: Gillian
posts.title: Edinburgh: Zen Lifestyle Spa & Salon
posts.text:
Dec 7, 2017 Dec 6, 2017 
Despite not actually having any Christmas parties to go to, this time of year always makes me want to indulge in some pampering, and update my beauty routine (and break out the glitter nail polish of course). I recently headed along to Zen Lifestyle for a wee pre-Christmas treat, and it was just the thing to get me feeling relaxed and ~zen~ ahead of the busy month of December. Custom Facials at Zen Lifestyle 
Zen Lifestyle kindly invited me along to try one of their custom facials. I’m pretty happy with my skincare routine at home so don’t often get a facial, but it’s nice to do it once in a while for a proper deep clean – and the chance to lie down and relax for an hour or so! 
Each facial starts off with a skincare consultation. My therapist asked me about the products I was currently using at home, what type of skin I had, and what my main skin concerns were. After taking a look at my skin, she then decided which products would be best suited to my skin type and condition. By getting this skin consultation at the start, it ensures each facial is personalised for each client so you get the full benefits. 
Zen Lifestyle use a lot of Murad products in the salon, so my therapist picked out the ones that would suit me best. As I have quite a bit of redness in my skin, we used a few from the Sensitive range – including the Soothing Gel Cleanser , the Sensitive Skin Soothing Serum and the Correcting Moisturiser . I also got a glycolic peel as part of the treatment, which left my skin feeling smooth, soft and radiant. 
The facial also included a head, shoulder and arm massage which was very relaxing. The treatment rooms at Zen Lifestyle are super cosy (you even get to snuggle up underneath a faux fur blanket!) so it was really easy to switch off and have a completely chilled out hour of pampering. Omnilux LED Facial Treatment 
After the main part of my facial was finished, I got to try out the Omnilux treatment. You can have this on its own, or combined with any of Zen’s other custom facials. The Omnilux is an LED machine which uses light to stimulate skin cells, counteract the effects of ageing and enhance the effect of skincare products. 
It was a bit weird at first – the light is SO bright, it feels a little bit like you’re being catapulted towards the sun – but you soon get used it. Omnilux promises to lift and hydrate your skin, improving your skin’s tone and texture, and smoothing out fine lines. It’s hard to tell whether the Omnilux or just the normal facial were responsible, but my skin certainly did look and feel great after the treatment. If you want to give your skin an extra little boost, I think the Omnilux LED treatment is definitely worth trying out. Worth a Visit? 
I have visited Zen Lifestyle quite a few times over the years for various treatments, including HD Brows, shellac manicures, massages and facials. They’re always a reliable option when you fancy a bit of pampering, and their central locations (on Hanover Street and Bruntsfield Place) make them easy to get to. 
The treatments are a little bit on the pricier side, with custom facials starting from £59 for 40 minutes or £79 for 60 minutes. But I think it’s totally worth it if you’re after a properly luxurious treatment or you have some skin concerns you want to work on. A relaxing facial or massage would also make a great Christmas present that’s thoughtful and a little bit special. Zen Lifestyle offer a range of vouchers for specific treatments, spa packages or monetary vouchers which can be redeemed against any treatment. Beauty

posts.title: BDA Advises FIS on Sale of Kingstar to Zhongping Capital
posts.text:
BDA Advises FIS on Sale of Kingstar to Zhongping Capital
New York, NY, BDA is pleased to announce that it was the exclusive financial advisor to FIS, a leading global financial software company, in the company’s transaction to sell its Chinese financial software subsidiary, SunGard Kingstar Data System (China), to Zhongping Capital. Zhongping is a leading alternative asset manager in China with over RMB30bn of assets under management. The transaction was signed Nov. 13 and is anticipated to close in the first quarter of 2018.
Simon Kavanagh, Managing Director, BDA Hong Kong said, “We’re delighted to have advised FIS on this competitive sale process. This is BDA’s fourth fintech transaction in the past 24 months, following on from successful sale processes for Thomson Reuters, VNPT ePay and Sungard. It reaffirms BDA’s position as one of Asia’s leading M&A advisors in the fintech sector, and continues our successful track record advising on MNC carve outs.”
BDA Deal Team
Paul DiGiacomo, Managing Director, Hong Kong
Simon Kavanagh, Managing Director, Hong Kong
Jeffrey Wang, Managing Director, Shanghai
Calvin Zeng, Associate, Shanghai
Evan Yang, Associate, Hong Kong
About FIS
FIS is a global leader in financial services technology, with a focus on retail and institutional banking, payments, asset and wealth management, risk and compliance, and outsourcing solutions. Through the depth and breadth of its solutions portfolio, global capabilities and domain expertise, FIS serves more than 20,000 clients in 130 countries. Headquartered in Jacksonville, Florida, FIS employs 53,000 people worldwide and holds leadership positions in payment processing, financial software and banking solutions. Providing software, services and outsourcing of the technology that empowers the financial world, FIS is a Fortune 500 company and is a member of Standard & Poor’s 500® Index. www.fisglobal.com
About Zhongping Capital
Zhongping Capital is a leading alternative asset manager in China with RMB30bn assets under management. Investing across finance services, TMT, healthcare, environmental services, new energy, and Industry 4.0, Zhongping aims to create long-term value for its investors by adopting a patient “buy-and-hold” investment approach and helping its portfolio companies achieve their full potential with implementation of growth and best-practice operational strategies. Zhongping Capital‘s vision is to create value for its investors, promote a prosperous society, provide professional development opportunities to its employees, and propel the economic growth of China. www.zhongpingcapital.com
About BDA
BDA Partners is a leader in cross-border investment banking involving Asia. BDA advises on M&A and capital raising. BDA has been consistently owned and managed by the same team since 1996. BDA has a track record of providing independent advice to blue-chip corporate and financial sponsor clients from North America, Europe, and Asia. BDA is headquartered in New York with offices in London, Dubai, Mumbai, Ho Chi Minh City, Singapore, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, and Tokyo. BDA formed partnerships with William Blair & Company in 2011 and Development Bank of Japan in 2017. www.bdapartners.com
US securities transactions are performed by BDA Partners’ affiliate, BDA Advisors Inc, a broker-dealer registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). BDA Advisors Inc. is a member of the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) and SIPC. In the UK, BDA Partners is authorised and regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). In Hong Kong, BDA Partners (HK) Ltd is licensed and regulated by the Securities & Futures Commission (SFC) to conduct Type 1 and Type 4 regulated activities to professional investors.

thread.section_title: Dreamz
thread.title: IRRESPONSIBLE & LAZY
thread.title_full: IRRESPONSIBLE & LAZY

posts.author: Rambler (noreply@blogger.com)
posts.title: IRRESPONSIBLE & LAZY
posts.text:
All my life I have been among irresponsible and lazy people - how I turned out to be the opposite of these people is indeed a mystery!  My mother, father, brother all come under this category.  These people are so consumed with there own comforts and eccentricities, that they do not know the damage they inflict, both on themselves and others. 

No amount of logical or good sense, make any impact on them.  I have struggled with these people for everything.  Having to take up a job at a very early age, due to family constraints, I had to leave very early in the morning as I worked in a hospital.  All through my stay with my parents, when I left in the morning to work, the whole house-hold would be asleep. No one cared about anything - they did as they pleased.  I would faithfully go about my business, not worrying about this.  When I returned home in the evening, everything would be a holy mess.  I would then get on to setting right whatever had to be set right, with always a silent prayer to God, to better the situation. 

Apparently God turned a deaf ear, as I landed up with a husband and children who also turned out to be like my parents. Everyone around me gets lazy and irresponsible -  I have to make up for all their short-comings, to hold on to a family.  This sustained attitude of others has taken its toll on me finally.  I have become frustrated and depressed.  What I would not give for a single soul in this house to be normal.  An ache which is never going to go away, until death do us part. 

Now, what gives people the right to do this to others and on top of that have no remorse.  I have been foolish and stupid, slogging around perfectly normal people for years that I have become the official laborer in my house. I love my family a lot, but I think I have over done my part.  I am caught in this mesh, a mesh everyone in my family wants me to be in, they do not want to give me a helping hand to extricate myself, as it would mean that they would have to turn around their life; which they are not willing to do and so I am stuck. 

But if you are young and you are caught in a situation like this, be a little self-fish and don't overdo. Don't be the first to take on responsibilities and be sure to protest loudly.  I had kept my mouth shut for too long, to reverse the situation, but you can learn from my mistake and turn around  your life, so that you don't land up like me. 

But, if you have a good supportive family, be sure to give a helping hand, be appreciative, do not take things for granted; for if you do, some day, for sure you will lose them.

thread.title: Beat cravings by understanding why you have them
thread.title_full: Beat cravings by understanding why you have them

posts.author: Holly Konig
posts.title: Beat cravings by understanding why you have them
posts.text:
Beat cravings by understanding why you have them Knowing how to beat cravings means understanding why you have them in the first place. 4 hours ago 
Cravings for certain foods – chocolate, salty crisps or bread – can seem habitual or sneak up on you. Knowing how to beat cravings means understanding why you have them in the first place. 
The food we eat influences our emotions. They have the ability to make us feel happy, depressed, anxious or calm, because certain foods trigger a release of brain chemicals called neurotransmitters, and they in turn control appetite and behaviour. 

Those dreaded carbs, for example, trigger a release of serotonin, the brain’s ‘happy chemical’. Protein, on the other hand, releases dopamine and noradrenaline, which spike energy levels. 
Joburg dietician Sue Scharf agrees. “A burning desire for a particular foodstuff is frequently linked to our emotions,” she says. 
On that note: Warm tummies with delicious chocolate banana bread 
Yet it can also point to an underlying medical issue, like an iron deficiency or diabetes, where the urge to eat certain foods is actually linked to a sugar imbalance. “If you have a natural predisposition to depression, blood sugar fluctuations will aggravate the condition,” she adds. 

So what does it mean when you guzzle a packet of potato crisps or a slab of chocolate? This is what your body may be trying to tell you: 
Chocolate: you may lack magnesium, which is essential for nerve function. You may also crave it when you’re down, or when you’re feeling ‘hormonal’ during your menstrual cycle. 
Salty foods: if there is no medical reason for it, a craving for salty food can be caused by stress, anger or frustration.

Shares of Axis Capital Holdings Limited (NYSE:AXS) hit a new 52-week low on Tuesday . The company traded as low as $50.30 and last traded at $51.16, with a volume of 777100 shares. The stock had previously closed at $51.64. 
A number of brokerages have weighed in on AXS. Buckingham Research began coverage on shares of Axis Capital in a report on Monday, September 11th. They set a “neutral” rating and a $58.00 target price on the stock. ValuEngine cut shares of Axis Capital from a “buy” rating to a “hold” rating in a report on Thursday, September 7th. Citigroup raised shares of Axis Capital from a “sell” rating to a “neutral” rating and set a $59.00 target price on the stock in a report on Monday, September 11th. UBS dropped their price objective on shares of Axis Capital from $57.00 to $55.00 and set a “sell” rating on the stock in a report on Monday, October 2nd. Finally, Zacks Investment Research cut shares of Axis Capital from a “hold” rating to a “sell” rating in a report on Tuesday, September 26th. Five analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have issued a hold rating and two have given a buy rating to the stock. The stock has an average rating of “Hold” and an average price target of $61.45. 
The company has a current ratio of 0.51, a quick ratio of 0.51 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.21. 
Axis Capital (NYSE:AXS) last released its quarterly earnings data on Wednesday, October 25th. The insurance provider reported ($5.35) earnings per share for the quarter, missing the Zacks’ consensus estimate of ($5.34) by ($0.01). Axis Capital had a negative return on equity of 2.59% and a negative net margin of 4.55%. The firm had revenue of $1.11 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $972.10 million. During the same period last year, the business earned $1.78 EPS. analysts predict that Axis Capital Holdings Limited will post -2.2 EPS for the current year. 
In other Axis Capital news, EVP Conrad D. Brooks sold 7,500 shares of the firm’s stock in a transaction dated Thursday, November 30th. The shares were sold at an average price of $52.31, for a total transaction of $392,325.00. Following the transaction, the executive vice president now owns 6,027 shares of the company’s stock, valued at approximately $315,272.37. The transaction was disclosed in a filing with the SEC, which can be accessed through this link . 1.89% of the stock is currently owned by company insiders. 
A number of institutional investors have recently added to or reduced their stakes in the business. California Public Employees Retirement System increased its stake in Axis Capital by 4.2% during the 3rd quarter. Cornerstone Capital Management Holdings LLC. now owns 75,921 shares of the insurance provider’s stock valued at $4,351,000 after buying an additional 51,180 shares during the period. Finally, Accident Compensation Corp increased its stake in Axis Capital by 150.8% during the 3rd quarter. posts.title: New shops on the scene
posts.text:
New on the shopping scene:
Ohana Cupcakes, Westfield North County, 200 Via Rancho Parkway, Escondido. (760) 746-4262 http://ohanacupcake.com
Ohana Cupcakes, a cupcake bakery and party purveyor in Oceanside, has launched a second store at the Westfield North County shopping center in Escondido. Kids (and adults) can choose their cupcake flavors and frosting and take home delicious one-of-a-kind cupcakes that are baked daily and sent over from the Oceanside store. Ohana Cupcakes also caters weddings, receptions, parties and corporate events and offers “party in a box,” custom cakes and more.
Chapter One Hair and Body Lab, 1317 S. Coast Highway, Oceanside; (760) 685-6143
Chapter One Hair and Body Lab is an education-driven space for cosmetologists and aestheticians to expand their knowledge and share their skills. A commercial salon by day and classroom by night, the Lab aims to bring together the best in personalized customer service and cutting-edge beauty and wellness education. The brainchild of Oceanside residents Christine Pierce, a seasoned stylist, and Kirstie Ennis, a U.S. Marine veteran, wounded warrior and extreme athlete, Chapter One has five experienced stylists who offer services including haircut, color, and styling as well as restorative massage. The salon features products by hair-care innovator Alter Ego Italy. Local partnerships include art by ManRabbit and clothing from Behold & See Co. The Lab is working with local nonprofits, including Feeding the Soul, and plans to host events benefiting the community.
James Pelar-Linova Photography / Fashionphile, an online consignment store for luxury handbags, has opened a showroom in Carlsbad. Fashionphile, an online consignment store for luxury handbags, has opened a showroom in Carlsbad. (James Pelar-Linova Photography /) Fashionphile, 6359 Paseo Del Lago, Carlsbad. Showroom hours by appointment only from 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Monday-Friday. Call ​(844) 619-8902; www.fashionphile.com .
Fashionphile is the leading online reseller of pre-owned luxury handbags since 1999. The newly redesigned Carlsbad HQ + Showroom merges fashion and tech for a shopping experience unlike any other. The expansive, open layout features exposed brick details and modern white interior for an industrial-inspired workspace. The second floor is The Cage, a high-security walk-in closet housing the multimillion-dollar inventory of luxury designer handbags ranging from Birkins, to classic Chanel, Louis Vuitton and more. Every item goes through an extensive vetting to guarantee authenticity. This vision of a safe and easy shopping destination to buy and sell luxury handbags has enabled thousands to reclaim designer bags and accessories at exceptional value.

thread.title: Ashes 2017/18: Nathan Lyon closing in on joining Australian 300-wickets club
thread.title_full: Ashes 2017/18: Nathan Lyon closing in on joining Australian 300-wickets club

posts.author: Chris Barrett
posts.title: Ashes 2017/18: Nathan Lyon closing in on joining Australian 300-wickets club
posts.text:
Spin king: Nathan Lyon in Adelaide Photo: AP 
Astoundingly, in Australian conditions and in a bowling line-up featuring Mitchell Starc, Josh Hazlewood and Pat Cummins – three of the best pacemen in the world – he has been the centrepiece of Steve Smith's attack, the man England's batsmen most fear. 
"Gazza is bowling the house down at the moment," Starc said on Thursday. 
"I think that allows the other three of us to do what we do from one end if need be. Josh does what he does and it allows Pat and I to bowl as fast as we can." 
Australia's well-rounded bowling department has fully justified the decision by national selectors not to include an all-rounder in the squad until now, with Mitch Marsh to join the camp in Perth. He could potentially make a return to the Test XI in place of a struggling Peter Handscomb. 
Thanks to the complementary roles played by the Australian quartet in repeatedly dismantling England, they haven't needed a fourth seamer. 
Lyon has been almost impossible for England's batsmen to get away, rocking them with over-spin and turn, Cummins has bowled with great control as well as pace, Starc has made in-roads with the new ball and taken down the tail and Hazlewood rose to the challenge on the last day in Adelaide, bowling faster than he ever had to be Australia's man of the hour. 
There is more bad news for England. 
"The exciting thing is I think our bowling group can still get better," Starc warned. 
"I think we've obviously managed to take 40 wickets in the last couple of weeks and do a lot of good things, but I think there is still room for improvement. 
"I think the fact that we've all sort of grown up together – well, Patty, Josh and I – we've been around each other for a long time. We spend so much time off the field as a group as well. We're really close mates. I think that shows in the way we play our cricket. We're gelling really nicely and we complement each other really well. 
"Hopefully we see a nice fast, bouncy wicket ... a WACA of old, and get stuck into their batters again as a bowling group." 
LEADING TEST WICKET-TAKERS FOR AUSTRALIA 
Shane Warne 708

thread.section_title: DRAGON
thread.title: Portrait of the artist: Michael Rosen / 'Kids don't get the chance to enjoy poetry'
thread.title_full: Portrait of the artist: Michael Rosen / 'Kids don't get the chance to enjoy poetry'

posts.author: Triunfo Arciniegas (noreply@blogger.com)
posts.title: Portrait of the artist: Michael Rosen / 'Kids don't get the chance to enjoy poetry'
posts.text:
Michael Rosen in his London studio. 
Photograph byFelix Clay 

Portrait of the artist Michael Rosen Writer 

'Kids don't get the chance to enjoy poetry. They're too busy counting adjectives' 


Laura Barnett
Tuesday 21 July 2009 00.05 BST 



What got you started? My parents. Both were teachers, and they believed poetry was a vital part of what you could offer kids. We had poems floating around the house, either on the shelves, or on vinyl and tapes – recordings of Dylan Thomas, Richard Burton and Robert Graves. What was your big breakthrough? Seeing my play Backbone put on at the Royal Court theatre in London in 1969, when I was still at university. I was overwhelmed: I'd sit in the audience, not quite knowing why I was there. What one piece of music would feature on the soundtrack to your life? Miles Davis's Freddie Freeloader. It gets your goosepimples going. Is there  a lot of backstabbing in the poetry world? Not in the children's poetry world – but yes, in the adult world. I was stunned by that whole Oxford poetry thing [the row between poets Derek Walcott and Ruth Padel]. It can't possibly matter that much. I was once involved in similar silliness myself, and Roger McGough put me down and said: "Is it good for poetry? If it isn't, shush." He was quite right. What's the greatest threat to poetry today? Comprehension questions in schools. Kids don't get the chance to get up and perform poetry, and enjoy it, because they're too busy counting adjectives and spotting metaphors. What advice would you give a young poet? Keep reading and listening to other poets. Don't think you've cracked it, because you never have. Is there an art form you don't relate to? Classical ballet. I can't see the emotion behind the movements; all I can see is pointy toes. What work of art would you most like to own? Netherlandish Proverbs, the painting by Bruegel. It was on our wall when I was a kid. It's such a wonderful idea: a visual manifestation of the oral wisdom of the people through their proverbs. What's the best advice anyone ever gave you? I used to show my dad a poem and he'd go: "Hmm, keep writing, lad." He was absolutely right: you have to keep bashing away at it. What's the biggest myth about poetry? That all of it is too hard. Some of it is – if you dive straight into Paradise Lost, it's pretty difficult – but not all of it. What's the worst thing anyone has ever said about you? A critic once described me as a "mere entertainer". But I didn't take it as an insult – being an entertainer is incredibly difficult. Is there anything about your career you regret? No, no, no. I've been just so crazily fortunate. In short Born: Harrow, 1946. Career: Has published more than 140 books. Was appointed children's laureate in 2007. The stage adaptation of his book We're Going On a Bear Hunt is at the Duchess, London WC2 (0844 412 4659), until 16 August. High point: "Being given the laureateship." Low point: "In 1990, when the big conglomerates moved into the children's book world, and I saw five of my titles wiped out overnight." 

THE GUARDIAN 



KISS 
Portrait of the artist / Liz Lochhead / "Do better next time" Portrait of the artist / John Cooper Clarke / At heart, I'm just a frustrated playboy Portrait of the artist / Alice Oswald / 'As a child, I wrote in a little notebook I hid in a bush' Portrait of the artist / Lemn Sissay / 'An artist doesn't need to suffer to create' 
DRAGON 001  Portrait of the artist / Will Alsop / 'I've learned never to trust anyone with big feet and a small head' 
Portrait of the artist / Jane Birkin / 'I was at the wrong audition, but Graham Greene still gave me my big break' 
Portrait of the artist / Vanessa Paradis/ 'I was only a teenager when I started out in the music industry. I didn't look my best' 
Portrait of the artist / Siri Hustvedt / 'I don't read reviews' 
Portrait of the artist / Michael Rosen / 'Kids don't get the chance to enjoy poetry'

posts.author: Anonymous
posts.text:
>>9348255
That's something I've talked about for years, both sides seem to have it in their heads that one is objectively superior and that intellect has some kind of upper bound (which it might but I don't think we're even close).
Improvements in biology will yield more improvement in biological and artificially based intelligence. At some point this should become a feedback loop where discoveries build on each other quickly enough to see gains in human intelligence inside of a decade, and leading to an escape velocity type situation where increases happen every few years, then months, then weeks.
The singularity will do one of two things, it will make us gods, or it will kill us all. Either way it should be a fun trip

posts.author: Lucid Stew
posts.text:
First of all, let me say this is excellent overall. I think your composition from all four angles is outstanding and dynamic. You have a real sense of movement and danger. I also appreciate the touch of comedy as our hero seems completely oblivious to the looming beast.
Proportions are very good. I think the wings on the beast could be a bit longer to help bridge that void between the characters.
My only real criticisms are in some of your value choices. In the monster in particular, value doesn't seem to vary much. Some darker values might help to give it a bit more depth. On Mister Hoover, the pants and coat being the same color and being dark gray takes away from this otherwise whimsical character. I'd like to see something less monochrome. Hopefully this feedback was useful.
